title-group.article-title: Applicability of small-scale models in prediction flutter pressure of delaminated composite beam-plates

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Ali A Yazdi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, P.O. Box 91775-1111, Mashhad, Iran. Email: aliaminyazdi@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study, the flutter pressure of delaminated composite beam-plates subjected to supersonic flow is investigated using similitude theory. An analytical investigation based on the direct use of the governing equations of the systems is undertaken to derive the necessary scaling laws and similarity conditions. The method presented herein has already been shown to be effective in the design of scaled down models for buckling and vibration response of laminated composite shells and panels. In this study, the flutter pressures of the prototypes are predicted by projecting the flutter pressure of the model using the derived scaling law. Based on the result of this study, for flutter of delaminated composite beam-plates, based on structural similitude, set of scaling laws can be found, which are used to develop design rules for small-scale models. For prototypes with the same material properties and stacking sequence as the prototype, distorted models with different delamination length and depth than those of the prototype can predict the behavior of the prototypes, accurately.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Composite materials have been widely employed in aerospace industries due to their outstanding mechanical properties. Therefore, the use of laminated composite media in structures presents the designer with the challenge of understanding the behavior of these materials in different situations. One of the primary reasons for such caution in the design procedure is a lack of thorough understanding of the failure mechanisms of composite structures. Unlike metals, where there are a few well-defined modes of failure, composite materials exhibit a wide variety of failure mechanisms such as delamination, matrix cracking, and fiber failure.

Delamination is a mode of failure of the composite structures due to their laminated nature. Delamination results in the loss of structural integrity and stiffness, and may cause a reduction in overall load bearing capacity of the structure. In this case, an understanding of failure or damage modes, their interactions, and their growth is an essential step during the design procedure.

In order to qualify the behavior of such structures, preliminary validation tests have to be done. These specific tests are usually very expensive and difficult to set up. An alternative method to reduce the amount of experimentation required is to use a similitude study. Similitude models allowing extrapolating the data of a small-scale model to predict the behavior of a real structure, herein called prototype. In the last two decades, this method was widely developed in the case of homogenous and composite materials, but such similitude techniques are not clearly identified for composite structures with delamination.

The flutter characteristics of two-dimensional (2D) delaminated composite panels at high supersonic Mach number were investigated by Shiau (1992). A simple beam-plate theory model is developed to predict the flutter boundaries of delaminated composite beam plates with simply supported ends.

Lee et al. (1993) investigated buckling of axially loaded composite beam plates with multiple delaminations. A finite element method based on a layer-wise plate theory was developed to study the effect of the different delamination parameter. Chang et al. (1998) studied the vibration of a delaminated composite plate subjected to the axial load. In this study, the continuous analysis concept was used to model the delaminated composite plate as a plate on a discontinuous elastic foundation.

Nam et al. (2000) investigated aeroelastic performance of smart composite wing in the presence of delaminations. A control system was designed to enhance the dynamic stability of the delaminated composite wing. Lee (2000) investigated free vibration of a laminated beam with delaminations using layer-wise theory. Finite element method is utilized to compare the numerical results with those of other theories addressing the effects of the lamination angle, location, size and the number of delamination on vibration frequencies of delaminated beams. The dynamics of a multi-layer composite plate with delaminations subjected to an aerodynamic load is studied by Ostachowicz and Kaczmarczyk (2001). In this study, the effect of embedded shape memory alloys (SMA) fibers on the natural frequencies of the plate subjected to supersonic flow is studied, and flutter instability boundaries are determined. Based on the results, the SMA fibers can be applied to modify these boundaries.

Lee et al. (2003) presented an analytical solution by using the free mode assumption. The frequency equations of multiple delaminated beams were obtained by dividing the global delaminated beam into beam segments and by imposing a recurrence relation from the continuity conditions on each sub-beam. These continuity conditions were determined by assuming a constant curvature at the delamination junctions. The results of their analytical model were verified using experimental and finite element results.

Other analytical solutions for composite beams with multiple delaminations were presented by Shu and Della (2004a, 2004b, 2005) based on the free mode and constrained mode assumptions. They examined the influence of a second delamination on the natural frequency and mode shape of the beam. Their studies showed that the presence of a second delamination significantly influence the natural frequency and the mode shape of the beam. However, the influence of a second short delamination (less than 25% of the beam length) is less significant.

Yang and Fu (2006, 2007) investigated the delamination growth of laminated composite cylindrical shells. They derived the post buckling governing equations for the laminated cylindrical shells, based on the variational principle of moving boundary, and the corresponding boundary and matching conditions are given. At the same time, according to the Griffith criterion, the formulas of energy release rate along the delamination front were obtained and the delamination growth was studied.

Oh et al. (2008) observed buckling analysis of a composite shell with multiple delaminations based on a higher order zig-zag theory. They developed a new three-node triangular shell element based on a higher order zig-zag theory for laminated composite shells with multiple delaminations. The baseline higher order zig-zag composite shell theory for multiple delaminations has been developed in a general curvilinear coordinate system and in general tensor notation.

Almost in all of the papers on delaminated structures, the emphasis has been on stability analysis problem, and few studies dealing with establishing similarity conditions for designing scaled down models to predict the behavior of delaminated composite beam-plates.
Rezaeepazhand et al. (1994) and Simitses et al. (1997) presented studies regarding the design of scaled down models for buckling and vibration of laminated composite plates and shells.

Chouchaoui and Ochoa (1999) demonstrated the validity of the scale model in predicting the behavior of a laminated cylindrical tube. Tensile, torsion, bending, internal and external pressure loads are considered in their study.

Friedmann and Presente (2001) investigated the applicability of aeroelastic scaling laws for general configuration. The main objective of this investigation is the development of innovative scaling laws for aeroelastic problems in compressible flow, where control is implemented either by conventional trailing-edge surface faces, or by piezoelectric induced actuation, so as to expand the flutter margin. Ungbhakorn and Singhatanadgid (2003) tried to derive the similitude invariants for the buckling load of anti-symmetric cross-ply and angle-ply laminated plates subjected to biaxial loads by applying the similitude transformation directly to the governing equations of the system.

Wu (2005) tried to determine the requirements for replacing a 2D full size rectangular plate with a 1D equivalent beam model and establishing the necessary scaling laws for constructing the scale beams from the last equivalent beam model are derived from the equations of motion.

To extend the applicability of the scaled down model Rezaeepazhand (2008) and Rezaeepazhand and Wisnom (2009) investigated the applicability of similitude theory in establishing necessary similarity conditions for designing scaled down models for predicting the buckling behavior of delaminated composite beam-plates.

Moreover, authors in their recent works investigated (Yazdi and Rezaeepazhand, 2011) the effect of delamination damage on flutter pressure of laminated composite plates using structural similitude analysis. This study is focused on angle-ply laminated plates. In this study, the effects of parameters such as fiber orientation and delamination positions were considered.

This article presents an analytical investigation for establishing the necessary similarity conditions for flutter of delaminated composite beam-plates. In this study, the flutter pressure of cross-ply and quasi-isotropic laminated plates are investigated. The governing equation is used to drive the necessary similarity conditions. These scaling laws are employed to predict the flutter pressure of the prototypes by projecting the flutter pressure of the model. For each parameter, the acceptable intervals and its limitations are discussed. In all cases, the analysis is restricted to linearly elastic material behavior.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
The composite beam in Figure 1 has a total length of L, thickness h, mass density per unit volume ρp. It contains a delamination of length d located at distance c from the left edge. It is assumed that the beam-plate is exposed to external supersonic flow along the positive x-direction. Quasi steady aerodynamic theory is used to obtain the flutter critical pressure. According to this theory, the aerodynamic pressure can be written as (1)Δp=ρU2M2-1(∂w∂x+M2-2M2-1∂w∂t) where U is air velocity, M is the Mach number, and ρ is air density. The 1D beam-plate, which is considered in this study, is a four-layer laminate. The composite material of the lamina is graphite/epoxy, and material properties are E1 = 13.643 E2, G12 = 0.493 E2, and v12 = 0.32. In all cases, in this study D is the bending stiffness of the beam-plate when all fibers aligned with x axis. Figure 1.
Composite beam with single delamination.

sec.title: Problem formulations
sec.p: There are two different approaches to establish similarity conditions between model and prototypes namely, dimensional analysis and direct use of the governing equations of the system. As mentioned in preceding section, the main objective of this investigation is the establishment of the similarity conditions between two similar structures based on the direct use of the governing equations of the system. In order to derive the governing equations of the delaminated composite beam-plate it is assumed that the delaminated beam is treated as four beams connected at the delamination boundaries. Due to the contact force between segments 2 and 3, the governing equation is a nonlinear equation. In this case, to simplify the analysis it is assumed that two segments that are separated from each other due to the delamination are forced to vibrate together; thus the governing equations for delaminated composite beam-plates are (Shiau, 1992) (2-a)D1∂4w1∂x4+ρph∂2w1∂t2+Δp=0 (2-b)(D2+D3)∂4w2∂x4+ρp(h2+h3)∂2w2∂t2+Δp=0 (2-c)D4∂4w4∂x4+ρph∂2w4∂t2+Δp=0 where wi (i = 1,2,4) is the lateral displacement of the plate, and Di is the reduced bending stiffness of the i-th beam. Equation (2) is the governing equation for flutter of both model and prototype. In this case, the first expression in equations (2) can be re-written for model and prototype as follows (3-a)D1pr∂4w1pr∂xpr4+ρpprhpr∂2w1pr∂t2+Δppr=0 (3-b)D1mo∂4w1mo∂xmo4+ρpmohmo∂2w1mo∂t2+Δpmo=0 where subscripts pr and mo refer to prototype and model, respectively. In the next section, the derivation of scaling laws based on direct use of governing equation is discussed, in detail.

sec.title: Establishing the necessary scaling laws
sec.p: The behavior of the model and its prototypes are modeled mathematically in terms of its structural geometric parameters and corresponding response parameters. The necessary and sufficient conditions of similitude between prototype and its scale model require that the mathematical model of the scale model can be transformed to that of the prototype by a bi-unique mapping. This transformation defines the necessary scaling laws or similarity conditions between all structural geometry parameters and the response of the two systems.
By defining the scale factor λx, all of the structural geometry parameters of two systems are connected to each other by a linear relation, as follows (Rezaeepazhand et al., 1994) (4)λx=xpr/xmo
The corresponding similarity conditions between model and prototype are defined by substituting equation (4) into equation (3-a) (5)(λD1λwλx4)D1mo∂4w1mo∂xmo4+(λρpλhλwλω2)ρpmohmo∂2w1mo∂t2+(λΔp)Δpmo=0

Equations (5) and (3-b) are the same if the terms in parentheses of equation (5) are all equal. In this case, the following scaling laws are obtained (6)λD1λa1-4=λρpλhλω2 (7)λD1λa1-4=λρλU2λβ-1λa1-1 where β=M2-1. In similar way, by applying similitude transformation into the equations (2-b) through (2-c) the following scaling laws can obtained (8)λD4λa2-3=λD1λa1-3 (9)λ(D2+D3)λd-4=λρλU2λβ-1λd-1 (10)λD4λa2-4=λρλU2λβ-1λa2-1 (11)λD1λa1-4=λρλU2λβ-1λa1-1 where ω is flutter frequency of delaminated composite beam-plate. Manipulating equations (7) through (11) gives an equation for λα as function of delamination length and depth as follows (12)λα4=λD1λD4λ(D2+D3)2λd-6λa1-3λa2-3 where α=ρU2/β. As it can be seen the bending stiffness ratio of the delaminated portion of the plate to the un-delaminated portion plays significant role in the prediction the flutter boundary of the delaminated composite beam-plate. Additionally, the continuity conditions at x = a1 are (13)w1(a1)=w2(a1) (14)∂w1(a1)∂x=∂w2(a1)∂x (15)V1(a1)=V2(a1)+V3(a1) (16)M1(a1)=M2(a1)+M3(a1)+P3h22-P2h32 where Pi (i = 2,3) are in-plane force induced by delamination. Similarly, we can derive the continuity conditions at x = a2. Applying similitude transformation to equation (15) and using definition of Vi the following scaling laws are obtained (17)Vi=ddx(-Did2wdx2) (18)λD1λa1-3=λD2λd-3=λD3λd-3
From equation (18) it can concluded that (19)λD1λa1-3=(λD2+λD3)λd-3=λ(D2+D3)λd-3

Comparing equation (19) with equation (9) and (11), one can deduce that these equations are the same. In this case, it can concluded that applying similitude theory to the boundary and auxiliary conditions dose not yield any new scaling laws. The accuracy of the derived scaling laws and the influence of different parameters on the accuracy of the distorted models are studied in the next section.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: This section presents the results obtained using the scaling law described above to study a simply support laminated beam-plate with single delamination. In order to verify the scaling laws and study the influence of different parameters, the predicted results are compared with the computed flutter pressures which are available in the literature (Shiau, 1992). Particular emphasis is placed on establishing the effects of different degrees of similarities, such as, the delamination length, delamination axial location and stacking sequence of the models or prototypes on the accuracy of the predicted results. Base on the scaling laws depicted by equation (12) the different possible scale models and the levels of confidence that can be expected from each model are discussed in the subsequent sections.

Figures 2 and 3 illustrate the effect of delamination length on flutter pressure of symmetric cross-ply laminated beam-plates. The scaling law depicted by equation (12) is used to predict the prototype flutter pressures. Three models with different delamination length are used to predict flutter pressure for a mid-plane and central delamination with different lengths. As it can be seen, the effect of the delamination increases as the delamination moves into the region of high shear force. Similar analysis is performed in Figure 4 for symmetric quasi-isotropic (90°/ ± 45°/0°)s laminated beam-plate. It is cleared that, model with delamination length 0.4 performs well in predicting flutter boundaries of prototypes. For shorter delamination length model (a/L = 0.3) the accuracy of the predicted results is decreased. This behavior can be attributed to the fact that the mode shapes of the model and prototype are not similar. It can be concluded that model with a/L = 0.4 yields the best results. Figure 2.
Influence of delamination length on predicted flutter pressure of symmetric cross-ply laminated (0°/90°)s beam (h2/h = 0.5).
Figure 3.
Influence of delamination length on predicted flutter pressure of symmetric cross-ply laminated (90°/0°)s beam (h2/h = 0.5).
Figure 4.
Influence of delamination length on predicted flutter pressure of quasi-isotropic laminated (90°/ ± 45°/0°)s beam (h2/h = 0.5).

In Figures 5 to 7 the accuracy of three models with different center point axial position of delamination in predicting flutter pressure of the prototypes are shown. In this case, all models have equal delamination length. Due to the symmetry of the problem only 0.2 ≤ c/L ≤ 0.5 is shown. It can be concluded from these figures that for a laminate with a fixed number of plies, for values of 0.2 ≤ c/L ≤ 0.5, the mid-plane model (c/L = 0.5) can predict flutter pressure accurately. Additionally, it should be noted that in the region near the edge of the beam, due to the local flutter mode shape effect, the discrepancy between the predicted and analytical results is increased. In this case, to improve the accuracy of the predicted value the effect of the local mode shape should be considered. Figure 5.
Influence of delamination axial position on predicted flutter pressure of symmetric cross-ply laminated (0°/90°)s beam (h2/h = 0.5, d = 0.2).
Figure 6.
Influence of delamination axial position on predicted flutter pressure of symmetric cross-ply laminated (90°/0°)s beam (h2/h = 0.5, d = 0.2). Figure 7.
Influence of delamination axial position on predicted flutter pressure of symmetric laminated (90°/ ± 45°/0°)s beam (h2/h = 0.5, d = 0.2).

Figure 8 presents the effect of delamination location through thickness on the accuracy of the predicted results for symmetric quasi-isotropic (90°/ ± 45°/0°)s laminated beam-plate. As it was shown, while delamination location moves from mid-plane to the top surface of delaminated beam plates through the thickness of plate the accuracy of the predicted results is decreased. This fact is due to the difference of flutter modes in comparison to the preceding conditions. In this case, to enhance the accuracy of the predicted results the effect of flutter modes should be imposed to the scaling law. Figure 8.
Influence of delamination through thickness location on the accuracy of the predicted results for symmetric laminated (90°/ ± 45°/0°)s beam.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study investigates the applicability of scale models in predicting the flutter pressure of delaminated composite beam-plate. Establishment of similarity conditions, based on the direct use of the governing equations, is discussed and their use in the design of models is presented. The accuracy of the predicted prototype flutter pressure by using various models is investigated. The results present herein indicate that, for flutter of the delaminated composite beam, based on structural similitude an expression can be introduced, which is able to predict the prototype flutter boundary accurately. Distorted models with the same material properties and stacking sequence as the prototype can predict the behavior of the prototype as long as the model and the prototype have the same mode shape. Additionally, it should be noted that the present scaling law cannot perform well in predicting results for short delamination length cases. This fact may be due to the effect of mode shape of the structures on the flutter boundaries. In this case, an approximate-analytical solution like Galerkin method should be utilized to obtain similarity conditions, but it was mentioned the aim of this study is to establish the similarity conditions based on direct use of governing equations not response of system.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
